newsitem.title: JAPAN: Softbank says weak yen boosts U.S. asset value.
newsitem.headline: Softbank says weak yen boosts U.S. asset value.

text.p: Thursday that the value of its dollar-based U.S. assets had risen by 20 percent as of the end of March 1997 due to the weak yen.

Company president Masayoshi Son told a news conference that the firm had spent about 500 billion yen to acquire U.S. assets since September 1994 and this investment had increased in value by 20 percent in yen terms as of March.
Son said the company expects its operating profit in the year to March 31, 1998, to reach 7.5 billion yen.
The company also said it had 250 billion yen worth of interest-bearing debt as of the end of March.
Son said Softbank aims to register the shares of some of its U.S. subsidiaries on the Nasdaq market in New York in the next few years.
It also plans to take a further two of its Japanese subsidiaries public in 1998. Softbank has already announced that it will list other Japanese units this year and next, including Yahoo! Japan.
Son also said operating profits of Softbank's subsidiaries outside Japan accounted for 75 percent of total group profit of 30.5 billion yen in fiscal 1996/97.
Overseas units contributed 48.9 percent of the group's total profit the previous year.
